metadata.title: Cerebral Palsy  Botulinum Toxin Type A Injections and Nonstandard Treatment Interventions -There was no difference in moderate/serious AEs between groups -Neurogenic atrophy in the medial gastrocnemius has been found to occur in patients with CP who received botulinum toxin type A injections(29) -Type 1 fiber loss was significantly related to the number of botulinum toxin type A injections -Injection of botulinum toxin type A in the salivary glands has been shown to be an effective treatment option for drooling in patients with spastic or dyskinetic CP(42) -Diagnostic tests completed:  Testing may consist of: -MRI to assess location and size of brain insult(44) -MRI is the preferred imaging test to evaluate the causes of CP and has a higher diagnostic yield compared to CT scans(44) -Cranial ultrasound(4) -X-ray  to evaluate orthopedic complications (e.g., scoliosis, femoral anteversion, hip dysplasia) -EEG assessment -Home remedies/alternative therapies:  Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help    -Previous therapy:  Document whether patient has had occupational therapy, physical therapy, speech therapy, or hippotherapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful –Aggravating/easing factors:  Note length of time each item is performed before the symptoms arise or are eased -Document any factors (e.g., position changes, activity, fatigue) that appear to exacerbate or ease spasticity, seizures, or any other symptoms –Body chart:  Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms –Nature of symptoms:  Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling) –Rating of symptoms:  Clinicians can use various scales to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much) -Visual analog scale (V AS) -FACES pain scale -Oucher pain scale –Pattern of symptoms:  Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night);also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables –Sleep disturbance:  Document number of wakings/night, if any –Other symptoms:  Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/ or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder dysfunction, saddle anesthesia) –Respiratory status:  Document any use of supplemental oxygen, ventilation, or respiratory therapy. Does the patient have any limitations due to respiratory problems? –Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe __________________________ •Medical history –Past medical history -General inquiry -Pregnancy and birth history (Note pertinent findings such as Apgar scores, weeks of gestation, birth weight, need for ventilation, manner of delivery, exposure to alcohol or drugs, as relevant) -Age at which developmental milestones were reached? -Has the patient undergone any surgical procedures? -Past hospitalizations and/or injuries? -Does the patient require a shunt? -Any spasticity management interventions (e.g., botulinum toxin injections, phenol, baclofen pump)? -Comorbid or other medical diagnoses:  Ask patient/caregiver about other problems, including seizures, dysphagia, diabetes, cancer, heart disease, sensory integration impairments, GERD, speech-language  disorders, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders -Medications previously prescribed:  Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs) -Other symptoms:  Ask patient/caregiver about other symptoms patients may be experiencing •Social/occupational history –Patient’s goals/inquiry -Document what the patient and caregiver hope to accomplish with therapy and in general -Describe the patient’s family structure/dynamics. Any siblings? -Does the family feel they have necessary support in place? -If a child, does the child attend school or is the child home-schooled? What is child’s grade level? If an adult, is the patient employed? What is the nature of the work? -What is the patient’s primary means of mobility? -How does the patient access the home/school/community? –Vocation/avocation and associated repetitive behaviors, if any -Is the patient involved in any recreational activities (sports, clubs, musical instrument, job)? -How much daily physical activity does the patient participate in? –Functional limitations/assistance with ADLs/adaptive equipment    -Does the patient utilize any assistive or adaptive devices? -How does patient manage ADLs? -How does patient manage bowel and bladder function? -How is the patient’s endurance throughout the day? -Does the patient drive? –Living environment -With whom does the patient live? Who are the primary caregivers? -Inquire about stairs, number of floors in home, use of wheelchairs or ambulatory assistive devices in the home. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary? Has a home safety check been performed by a professional? -Inquire about family’s vehicle, ability of patient to get in and out, ability to transport necessary devices, any modifications necessary -Is the patient able to safely negotiate all environments (home, school, community)? -Can the child reach the classroom in a timely manner? -Are additional modifications necessary?
synonyms: cerebral  botulinum toxin type a injections and nonstandard treatment interventions
botulinum toxin type a injections and nonstandard treatment interventions: cerebral palsy
injections, botulinum toxin type a and nonstandard treatment interventions: cerebral palsy
anatomical location body part affected: Cerebral palsy (CP) results from a lesion in the developing brain. This affects the development of the total child. Classification can be based on anatomical location most affected, as follows:(22)
Diplegia – lower extremities are more involved than upper extremities
Hemiplegia – one side of the body is affected by CP; injury to brain located principally in one hemisphere
Quadriplegia or tetraplegia – all extremities are affected similarly
Less common combinations of limb involvement include monoplegia, double hemiplegia (all four limbs involved with asymmetry between the sides), and triplegia
reimbursement: Depending on their geographic location, persons with CP living in the United States may be eligible for government-funded  therapy programs.(2) Nonstandard treatment interventions include therapies typically not paid for by insurance or state programs(23)

Presentation/signs and symptoms:  Classification for types of CP can vary; the types listed below are from the United Cerebral Palsy Foundation. Signs and symptoms as well as certain secondary impairments are listed from various references –General signs and symptoms of CP -Persistent primitive reflexes (asymmetric tonic neck, Moro reflex, etc.)(44) -Atypical muscle tone and deep tendon reflexes(18) -Cognitive impairment (two-thirds  of individuals with CP)(18) -Dyspraxia(22) -Sensory perception impairments(18) -Speech and language disorders(18) -Seizures(18) -Hearing loss(18) -Feeding difficulties -Visual impairments(18) –Spastic CP(22) -Seventy to eighty percent of children with CP(18) -May develop after a hypotonic period in infancy -Hypertonicity is present in various patterns; increased co-contraction  of muscle groups is seen -Degree of spasticity varies among children and can vary within the child depending on the activity -The impact of the child’s hypertonia on his or her functional abilities varies according to type of spastic CP (quadriplegia, diplegia, hemiplegia). With all types, however, developmental motor milestones, ROM, strength, balance, postural tone, coordination, and protective reactions will be affected to some degree -Muscle groups may appear or become weak due to spasticity in the opposing muscle group –Ataxic CP (22) -Rare form; 5–10%  of CP cases -Affects balance and coordination and alters depth perception -Gait is usually wide-based -Intention tremor may be observed -Associated with hypotonia, including low postural tone -Developmental motor milestones delay is common -Visual motor skills may be impaired such as moving eyes separately from the head; tracking, and eye-hand  coordination –Athetoid or dyskinetic CP (22) -Ten to twenty percent of CP cases -Dyskinesia is an umbrella term for numerous movement disorders, including chorea, athetosis, and dystonia -Chorea: abrupt, jerky movements -Athetosis: slow, writhing, persistent movements in the extremities -Dystonia: writhing movements leading to sustained atypical postures –Postural tone fluctuates and is typically low -Difficulty sustaining postures against gravity -Impaired co-contraction  of muscle groups; movements are jerky and lack flow -Unable to grade the speed and degree of desired movements  -Hypermobility in most joints -Altered respiration –Mixed CP(22) -A patient may have symptoms of two different types of CP, often spastic CP with athetoid movements –Please see Clinical Review…Cerebral Palsy: Spastic Hemiplegia , referenced above –Please see Clinical Review…Cerebral Palsy: Spastic Diplegia , referenced above –Please see Clinical Review…Cerebral Palsy: An Overview , referenced above –Please see Clinical Review…Cerebral Palsy: Speech Therapy ; Topic ID Number: T708777 –Please see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Cerebral Palsy (Children) ; Topic ID Number: T708945 Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
presentation signs and symptoms: Classification for types of CP can vary; the types listed below are from the United Cerebral Palsy Foundation. Signs and symptoms as well as certain secondary impairments are listed from various references –General signs and symptoms of CP -Persistent primitive reflexes (asymmetric tonic neck, Moro reflex, etc.)(44) -Atypical muscle tone and deep tendon reflexes(18) -Cognitive impairment (two-thirds  of individuals with CP)(18) -Dyspraxia(22) -Sensory perception impairments(18) -Speech and language disorders(18) -Seizures(18) -Hearing loss(18) -Feeding difficulties -Visual impairments(18) –Spastic CP(22) -Seventy to eighty percent of children with CP(18) -May develop after a hypotonic period in infancy -Hypertonicity is present in various patterns; increased co-contraction  of muscle groups is seen -Degree of spasticity varies among children and can vary within the child depending on the activity -The impact of the child’s hypertonia on his or her functional abilities varies according to type of spastic CP (quadriplegia, diplegia, hemiplegia). With all types, however, developmental motor milestones, ROM, strength, balance, postural tone, coordination, and protective reactions will be affected to some degree -Muscle groups may appear or become weak due to spasticity in the opposing muscle group –Ataxic CP (22) -Rare form; 5–10%  of CP cases -Affects balance and coordination and alters depth perception -Gait is usually wide-based -Intention tremor may be observed -Associated with hypotonia, including low postural tone -Developmental motor milestones delay is common -Visual motor skills may be impaired such as moving eyes separately from the head; tracking, and eye-hand  coordination –Athetoid or dyskinetic CP (22) -Ten to twenty percent of CP cases -Dyskinesia is an umbrella term for numerous movement disorders, including chorea, athetosis, and dystonia -Chorea: abrupt, jerky movements -Athetosis: slow, writhing, persistent movements in the extremities -Dystonia: writhing movements leading to sustained atypical postures –Postural tone fluctuates and is typically low -Difficulty sustaining postures against gravity -Impaired co-contraction  of muscle groups; movements are jerky and lack flow -Unable to grade the speed and degree of desired movements  -Hypermobility in most joints -Altered respiration –Mixed CP(22) -A patient may have symptoms of two different types of CP, often spastic CP with athetoid movements –Please see Clinical Review…Cerebral Palsy: Spastic Hemiplegia , referenced above –Please see Clinical Review…Cerebral Palsy: Spastic Diplegia , referenced above –Please see Clinical Review…Cerebral Palsy: An Overview , referenced above –Please see Clinical Review…Cerebral Palsy: Speech Therapy ; Topic ID Number: T708777 –Please see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Cerebral Palsy (Children) ; Topic ID Number: T708945 Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

causes: The cause is often obscure or multifactorial(18)
Congenital CP – Prenatal or perinatal injury to the child’s brain(22)
Acquired CP – Postnatal injury to the brain well after birth, typically by age 2. It can be the result of infection, traumaticbrain injury (TBI), anoxia, or ischemia(1,22)
Ten to fifteen percent of cases of CP are acquired(22)
Seventy percent of CP cases are of unknown etiology
pathogenesis: An injury occurs in a region or multiple regions in the brain, causing permanent damage to the brain tissue during theperiod of infant brain development
This injury may occur prenatally, perinatally, or postnatally(18)

The insult to the immature brain primarily affects the child’s musculoskeletal system, including strength and motorcontrol; however, the motor disturbances are often accompanied by disturbances of sensation, perception, cognition,communication, and behavior(1)
CP is not a progressive neuromuscular disorder
risk factors prenatal: Maternal disease during pregnancy (respiratory or cardiac disease, seizures; incompetent cervix)(1)
Chorioamnionitis – the membranes that cover the fetus become inflamed
Mother and infant blood type incompatibility
risk factors postnatal ,: Injury (e.g., motor vehicle accident, child abuse)

overall contraindications precautions: Contraindications to use of botulinum toxin type A(49) Excessive weakness Fixed contractures Neuromuscular diseases such as myasthenia gravis, Lambert-Eaton  syndrome, and motor neuron diseases Pregnancy and lactation Use of aminoglycosides Botulinum toxin type A injections : Clinicians should be aware that swallowing difficulties and breathing difficulties are rare but serious complications of botulinum toxin type A treatment that may occur at any time during the first week after the treatment.(19) If these complications occur, emergency medical care should be obtained

Training New clinicians may require training on the emotional needs of the parents during what may be a challenging time; training should include the importance of demonstrating an appropriate amount of empathy/sensitivity New clinicians may require additional education or mentoring to treat children with CP Clinicians should incorporate the family/caregivers in the treatment sessions and goal setting, explain and demonstrate therapeutic strategies, and provide oral and written instruction as indicated

Pressure orthoses Contraindicated in patients with seriously compromised lung function Contraindicated when intractable peripheral cyanosis is present; commonly found in individuals with low activity levels and significant motor impairment
Fractures Individuals with CP have an increased risk of fractures due to an underdeveloped musculoskeletal system, excess body fat, and reduced mechanical loading(45)

Seizure disorders Patients experiencing unexplained refractory seizures should have a lumbar puncture(44) General guidelines for patients experiencing a seizure(3) –Protect the patient from harm; eliminate dangerous objects from area –Stay with the patient –Do not hold down extremities –Release restrictive clothing –Aspiration precautions: rotate head to side, assess airway, wait for tonic-clonic  activity to pass before administering artificial respiration if indicated
Feeding tubes: Clinicians should be aware of any feeding tubes and take appropriate precautions in handling/treatment
Oral/motor dysfunction: Consult with family and other healthcare providers for restrictions
GERD: Consult with family/healthcare providers for restrictions/healthcare plan related to a diagnosis of GERD. Try to schedule therapy sessions either before or several hours after a meal
Impaired safety awareness: A child with CP may present with impairments in the areas of cognition and/or vision. Assess level of supervision necessary to maintain safety during mobility activities
Botulinum toxin can cause paralysis of the respiratory muscles, which can lead to death(50)

Cerebral shunts: Therapist should be aware of and monitor for signs and symptoms of shunt malfunction, and be aware of any precautions that may be in place regarding elevation of child’s head (e.g., head of bed elevated > 30 degrees)
See specific  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan of Care

contraindications precautions: Respiratory compromise with vital capacity less than 1 liter
Over the trunk or heart region in patients with demand-type  pacemakers and implantable cardioverter defibrillators (ICDs)
Over the pelvic, abdominal, lumbar, or hip region of a pregnant woman
Over the phrenic nerve, eyes, or gonads
Over areas of known peripheral vascular disease
With patients with compromised mental ability
With cardiac dysfunction (uncontrolled hypertension or hypotension, irregular heartbeat)
With electrodes -Over compromised skin, unless treating wound specifically -Over tissues that are vulnerable to hemorrhage
Cervical region in patients with history of stroke or seizures
over the region of a cardiac pacemaker
over the pelvis, abdominal, and lumbar regions during pregnancy
in an area with infection or bleeding
if a benign or malignant tumor is present in the area
in the area of a DVT or thrombophlebitis
over the heart, stellate, or cervical ganglia
individuals who cannot communicate effectively (e.g., impaired cognition, language barriers)
Note: Always decrease ultrasound intensity if the patient complains of discomfort
Sufficient training is required for hippotherapists
All clients must wear protective gear
All horses must be deemed to be safe by the program during a trial period prior to working with clients
for persons with atlantoaxial instability, an intense fear of horses, allergies to horses, grand mal seizures, fractures, or tethered cord syndrome
for persons who do not meet the age or weight criteria of the hippotherapy program selected
if it causes a decline in function or an increase in pain
other: Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies

Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regards to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary listed below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols
Only qualified healthcare professionals may administer botulinum toxin injections
Therapeutic ultrasound  contraindications include; do not use:(16)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Most children with CP will require periodic PT throughout their lives. Intervention should be tailored to meet the needs of the child/family at each particular stage of development. The facets of PT intervention are numerous but generally include prevention of deformity, pain reduction, maximizing mobility/function, and patient/family

decreased spasticity: Modified Ashworth Scale or Tardieu Scale

maintenance or prevention: Home exercise program should be implemented with focus on: increasing or maintaining ROM as indicated and appropriate preventing pressure sores orthotic wearing schedule exercises/activities to maximize strength, balance, and function
Recommendations for routine follow-up  with medical team
patient education: Care.com, “Caring for a Child with Cerebral Palsy,” https://www.care.com/special-needs-caring-for-a-child-with-cerebral-palsy-p1167-q227930.html
“Treatment for Cerebral Palsy,” MyChild at CerebralPalsy.Org, http://www.cerebralpalsy.org/about-cerebral-palsy/treatment

United Cerebral Palsy http://ucp.org/ Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
